fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The sphere \mathbb {S}^n can be constructed as an effective simplicial set with exactly two geometric simplices: a zero-dimensional point, and an n-dimensional surface. All the faces of the surface are degenerate and comes from the point.
The associated reduced ACC is \mathbb {Z} at degree 0 and n and zero elsewhere. The map d is constant zero.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic cellular complexes associated with a simplicial set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an (effective) simplicial set X, there are two major algebraic cellular complexes (or chain complexes) we can associate to it. We can consider the free abelian group generated by \Gamma ( \Delta ^n, X) at degree n, where the boundary map is given by an alternating sum of face maps: d_n = \sum _{i=0}^n (-1)^{i} \partial _i. This satisfies d^2 = 0 by the simplicial identities. ALternatively, we can consider only the geometric simplices, regarding degenerate ones are zero. More formally, we quotient out the previous chain complex by the subgroups generated by degenerate simplicies. They are both obviously effective by construction.

The first chain complex is called the non-reduced complex, while the second one is the reduced complex. By the two chain complexes are related by a chain reduction. So we will write C_* X for the reduced complex, leaving no notation for the non-reduced one unless otherwise stated.

An effective simplicial set consists of a sequence of types \operatorname {Geom} _n(X) with decidable equality, representing the geometric, a.k.a. non-degenerate, simplices. The full set of simplices, written \Gamma ( \Delta ^n, X) or more simply X_n, is given by a geometric simplex g \in \operatorname {Geom} _k(X) for some k together with a degeneracy symbol, defined as a surjection \eta : [n+1] \twoheadrightarrow [k+1], formally representing the degeneracy map that brought g up to dimension n, written as \eta ^* g. The effective simplicial set is also required to have computable face maps \partial _i : \operatorname {Geom} _{n+1}(X) \to \Gamma ( \Delta ^n, X) for 0 \le i \le n+1, so that the usual simplicial identities hold. The simplicial set is of finite type if each \operatorname {Geom} _n(X) is computably finite.

Alternatively, we can make a definition that more closely follows the traditional one, requiring a sequence of types with decidable equality representing all simplices instead of geometric ones. We then need to impose an additional requirement that the degeneracy of a simplex is decidable. The equivalence of the two definitions is given by the Eilenbergâ€“Zilber lemma.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reduction from K( \mathbb {Z}, 1) to the circle

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is a chain reduction from the bar construction \bar {W} (G) of a group regarded as its reduced algebraic cellular complex, to the circle \mathbb {S}^1.

By construction, the geometric simplices of K( \mathbb {Z}, 1) are lists [a_1 \mid a_2 \mid \cdots \mid a_n] of non-zero integers. We construct an admissible discrete vector field and use the reduction it generates. We assign a cell [a_1 \mid \cdots ] as a source if a_1 \ne 1. If a_1 \le 0, then we assign its target cell to be [1 \mid a_1 \mid \cdots ]; otherwise we assign [1 \mid a_1 - 1 \mid \cdots ]. Hence, the critical cells are [] and [1].
